record.title: PARLIAMENTARY INQUIRY
record.narrative:
PARLIAMENTARY INQUIRY -- (House of Representatives - October 17, 2007)

[Page: H11720]

speaking-unknown-id.title: Ms.
speaking-unknown-id.name: SCHULTZ, WASSERMAN
speaking-unknown-id.paragraph: Mr. Speaker, I have a parliamentary inquiry.

record.chair: The gentlewoman will state her inquiry.

speaking-unknown-id.title: Ms.
speaking-unknown-id.name: SCHULTZ, WASSERMAN
speaking-unknown-id.paragraph: Mr. Speaker, my understanding of the rule that you just cited is that Members need to refrain from making direct accusations of the President's being deceptive or referring to the President as a prevaricator or any other word that might apply.

What I did on the House floor this evening was read from a newspaper editorial's opinion. I did not directly make any reference. So I wanted to make sure that we clarify that that was not a violation of the rules.

record.chair: The gentlewoman is incorrect. The House rules do not permit a Member to make an improper statement under the guise that it is a quote from another.

speaking-unknown-id.title: Ms.
speaking-unknown-id.name: SCHULTZ, WASSERMAN
speaking-unknown-id.paragraph: I will take that under advisement, Mr. Speaker, but that is something that I would like to look into on my own and would be happy to follow up with the Parliamentarian. Thank you.
